oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Major Ridge Home: oblique view of front with Chieftains commemorative plaque
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a white panel house with historic landmark sign reading "Chieftans"; house has two wings with each three arched windows; main part has one-story porch, two brick chimneys, and nine rectangular windows

Major Ridge was an important Cherokee leader who is most remembered as a signer of the Treaty of New Echota that sold Cherokee land to the U. S. Government in exchange for land in Oklahoma, leading to the removal of most Cherokee from Georgia via the Trail of Tears. Originally from the Hiwassee River area of Tennessee, Ridge moved his family to a site along the Oostanaula River, where he operated a ferry, trading post and farm. The original dogtrot cabin built by Major Ridge circa 1800 is incorporated in the modern Major Ridge Home. Conversion of the cabin to a clapboard plantation home was done by Ridge, with significant modernization done since. The house is now part of the Chieftains Museum.
